title: Analysis of the interplay between hepatitis B virus-positive hepatocytes and Kupffer cells ex vivo using mice as a model

Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Hydrodynamic injection
Timing: 30 min
The use of hydrodynamic injection for gene delivery into mouse hepatocytes was first reported more than 20 years ago (Liu et al., 1999[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]; Zhang et al., 1999[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]). The volume of the DNA solution used for the injection is about 8% of the mouse body weight. The solution is injected rapidly into mice via the tail vein within 5–8 s.
Prepare reagents and instruments required for hydrodynamic injection and mouse blood collection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).

Figure 1. Hydrodynamic injection
(A) Reagents and the apparatuses needed for the injection.
(B) Dilating the tail blood vessels with a heat lamp.
(C) Anesthetizing the mouse with ketamine.
(D) Immobilizing the mouse with a restraining device.
(E) Inserting the needle in the distal portion of the tail vein and injecting the DNA solution into the tail vein.
(F) Removing the mouse from the restrainer for recovery.
Select 8-week-old C57BL/6 mice weighing about 19–25 g.
Mix 20 μg HBV DNA with a volume of DPBS equivalent to 8% of the mouse body weight. For a 20-gram mouse, the volume is approximately 1.6 mL.
Dilate tail blood vessels by warming mice with a heat lamp (120 W bulb) for 3–5 min before performing the injection (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Critical: Be cautious not to overheat the mice such as by putting the lamp too close to the mice or warming the mice for too long. Excessive movements or sweating of mice is a sign of overheating. Alternatively, the tail can also be warmed in 50°C water for a couple minutes.
Dilute ketamine10-fold with DPBS and anesthetize the mouse by intraperitoneal (i.p.) injection of 20 μL of the diluted ketamine (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Immobilize the mouse with a mouse restrainer (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).

With the heat lamp on, locate the dilated vein on the ventral side of the mouse tail, preferably near the tip of the tail.
Wipe the intended injection site with an alcohol pad for disinfection and to further increase the visibility of the vein.
Add 8% body weight-equivalent of the DNA-saline solution to the syringe. Connect the needle to the syringe and make sure there are no air bubbles.
Note: With the needle facing up, tap the syringe with your finger a few times to move the air bubbles to the needle, and then carefully expel the air until a small amount of solution is removed.
With the syringe needle beveled side up and nearly parallel to the mouse tail, insert the needle in the distal portion of the tail. This allows a better view of the needle when it enters the vein. Inject the entire volume of the DNA solution into the tail vein of the mouse with a constant speed and complete the injection within 5–8 s (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E).
Critical: The injection speed is critical for obtaining a good DNA transfection efficiency of hepatocytes.
Remove the mouse from the restrainer and place it into the cage for recovery (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F).
Mouse blood collection for serologic assays
Timing: 4 h
Here is an easy method for the collection of 100–500 μL blood from the mouse facial vein. This method involves the anesthetization of the mouse, the pricking of the freckle with a lancet, and the collection of the blood. Note that HBV is a human pathogen and therefore people working with mice should be vaccinated against HBV.
Collect blood from the mouse facial vein on day 3 after hydrodynamic injection.

To collect the blood, place the non-dominant hand on the mouse, then use the thumb and index finger to grasp the mouse. Find the hairless freckles on the side of the jaw.
Pick up the lancet with the other hand. Point the lancet at the distal end of the mouse’s face near the base of the ear or the base of the distal end of the mouth. Prick the freckle with a lancet (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A).
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/1628-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Mouse blood collection and measurement of HBsAg and HBeAg
(A) Pricking the freckle of the mouse with a lancet.
(B) Collecting blood from the facial vein.
(C) Centrifugation and collection of the serum.
(D) Measuring the levels of HBsAg and HBeAg in the mouse serum by ELISA. The results represent the mean ± SEM.
Collect 100–500 μL of blood in a 1.5 mL Eppendorf tube (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]B). After collecting the blood sample, put the mouse back into the cage. Bleeding should stop immediately.
Centrifuge the sample at 12,000 × g for 5 min at 18°C–25°C.
Transfer the supernatant (i.e., the serum) to a new Eppendorf tube and store the serum at −20°C (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]C).
Pause point: Serum can be stored at −20°C or −80°C.
As an injection control, measure HBV surface antigen (HBsAg) and e antigen (HBeAg) levels using the HBsAg and HBeAg ELISA kits following the manufacturer’s protocols[href=https://www.intlimmunodiagnostics.com/eia-hepatitis] (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]D).
Isolation of hepatocytes and Kupffer cells from mouse liver
Timing: 3 h

Here is the method to isolate hepatocytes and Kupffer cells from the mouse liver. This method yields hepatocytes and Kupffer cells with a high viability and purity. In this method, the mouse liver is perfused twice: the first one with a solution containing EGTA and BSA, and the second one with a solution containing collagenase. The purpose of the first step is to remove calcium ions (i.e., by EGTA) from epithelial cells to cause the rapid destruction of intercellular junctions and the loss of cell–cell contacts. The second step is to use collagenase to disrupt the supporting extracellular matrix of liver lobes. This is followed by the use of Percoll to isolate hepatocytes and the use of the OptiPrep density gradient to separate Kupffer cells from other nonparenchymal cells (NPCs).
Reagents
Pre-warm Solution A and Solution B in a 42°C water bath.
Prepare 70% ethanol solution (in spray and in a bottle).
Autoclave at least 50 mL of water (needed for washing the pump system each time).
Instruments
Mini-pump with size 14C tube.
Water bath (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A).

Surgical tools (scissors, forceps, sutures, syringes, and catheters (24 gauge for mouse) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Protocol (See also Methods Video S1[href=https://www.wicell.org#mmc1]).
Procedures for cleaning the pump.
Pre-clean the pump with 70% ethanol solution for more than 5 min.
Flush the pump system with at least 50 mL of autoclaved water and ensure that all the water is completely removed.
Fill the pump system with Solution A.
Circulate Solution A (38°C–39°C) through the pump using a pumping rate of 7 mL/min.
Critical: Pre-warming Solution A is essential for improving the cell viability.
Anesthetize the mouse with ketamine as described in step 7.
Apply 70% ethanol to the mouse abdomen for disinfection.
Place the sedated mouse on the operation board and fix the mouse legs with the tape to the board.
Open the abdominal cavity.
Cut open the mouse abdomen (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Move the intestine to the right to uncover the venous systems (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C).
Insert the suture.
Place a suture under the upper part of the portal vein (suture 1).
Hold both ends of the suture with a hemostat (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]D).
Place another suture under the upper part of the vena cava (beside the right kidney) and tie a loose knot (suture 2) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]E).
Open the thoracic cavity.
Open the thoracic cavity by cutting the diaphragm and chest bones beside the xiphisternum.
Grab the xiphisternum with a tweezer and open the chest over the mouse face to unveil the heart.
Turn the operation board around and puncture the heart’s center using the sharp end of a 24-gauge catheter.

Insert the 24-gauge catheter, which is connected to the tube in Solution A, into the right auricle and allow the catheter to reach the inferior vena cava downstream of the liver (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]F).
Critical: This is a critical step for a successful liver perfusion. It is essential to ensure that the catheter reaches the inferior vena cava downstream of the liver. This is important for the uniform distribution of the solution for liver digestion.
Perfuse the liver with Solution A.
Cut the inferior vena cava.
Start the perfusion of Solution A at a flow rate of 7 mL/min.
Cut the portal vein with a scissor after lifting suture 1. Do not cut the suture.
Lift suture 2 by grabbing both suture ends to remove remaining blood in the liver and then tie suture 2. Both steps c and d need to be carefully performed to allow smooth perfusion of Solution A.
Perfuse the liver with a total volume of 50 mL of Solution A.
Carefully monitor the flowing of Solution A through the liver.
The color of the liver should turn pale (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]G).
This step should be done as quickly as possible.
Perfuse the liver with Solution B.
After the perfusion of 50 mL Solution A, transfer the liquid inflow tube of the perfusion pump to the tube containing pre-warmed Solution B. Be careful not to trap any air bubble.
Perfuse the liver with at least 25 mL but no more than 40 mL of Solution B at the flow rate of 7 mL/min.Continue the perfusion until the liver is swollen and shiny.
Breakage of the liver can be seen.
Stop the pump and cut the inferior vena cava in the upper region of suture 2.
Isolation of Liver Cells.

Quickly remove the liver from the mouse abdominal cavity (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]H).
Place the liver in a petri dish with 35 mL of Solution C (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]H).
Hold the liver with tweezers and gently tap the perfused liver to disperse cells from the liver (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]I).
Continue the process until all liver lobes disintegrate and separate into single cells (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]J).
Filter liver cells with a 70 μm nylon cell strainer.
Centrifuge the cells in a 50 mL tube at 60 × g for 2 min with both acceleration and break set at 3 to separate NPCs (supernatant) and hepatocytes (pellet) (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]K).
Purification of Hepatocytes.
Prepare the Percoll solution by mixing 5.2 mL of 10× Percoll buffer with the Percoll stock solution to a final volume of 40 mL. Keep the Percoll solution at 4°C.
Transfer the supernatant, which contains NPCs, to a new tube on ice for later purification of Kupffer cells and leave behind a little bit more than 3 mL of the solution and the pellet, which contained hepatocytes, in the tube.
Add 30 mL of diluted Percoll solution to the pelleted cells in the tube. Gently resuspend the cells by pipetting. Avoid vortexing.
Centrifuge at 1,200 × g in Eppendorf 5804R centrifuge for 3 min at 18°C–25°C.
Cells pelleted are purified hepatocytes.
Count cells and seed them (at a density of 0.3 × 106/mL) in hepatocyte culture medium in a collagen-coated plate (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).

Figure 4. Hepatocytes and Kupffer cells purified from the mouse liver
(A) The morphology of hepatocytes two days after plating.
(B) The morphology of Kupffer cells. In both (A) and (B), the scale bar is 20 μm.

(C–F) Analysis of the purity of Kupffer cells by flow cytometry. Kupffer cells on petri dishes were collected by trypsinization at 37°C for five minutes, and 2 × 105 Kupffer cells were incubated with isotype control antibodies (red) or antibodies against cell markers of interest (blue) on ice for 30 min. Cells were then rinsed with DPBS three times and subjected to flow cytometry for the analysis of F4/80 (C), dead cells using Fixable Blue Dead Cell Staining Kit (D), CD11b and CD45 (E), and TIM-4 and CD45 (F). Panel (C) was adapted from Figure S1A of Li et al. (Li et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]). Panels (D) and (E) were from different experiments.
Purification of Kupffer Cells.
Centrifuge the supernatant isolated in step 33b at 583 × g for 8 min at 18°C–25°C.
Resuspend the cell pellet in 5.5 mL DMEM and overlay cells on a step gradient consisting of OptiPrep Density Gradient Media with densities of (from top to bottom) 1.035 (1.5 mL), 1.042 (1.5 mL), 1.056 (1.5 mL) and 1.081 (2 mL). Overlay the centrifuge tube with additional DMEM if necessary.
Centrifuge at 21,400 × g for 20 min at 18°C–25°C using a Beckman SW40Ti rotor.
Isolate Kupffer cells at the interface of densities 1.042 and 1.056, mix with 5 mL DMEM in a 15 mL tube, and pellet cells at 583 × g for 8 min at 18°C–25°C.
Resuspend Kupffer cells in 5 mL DMEM.
Pellet cells at 583 × g and resuspend cells in 5 mL DMEM. Repeat this step one more time to rinse Kupffer cells.
Remove the supernatant carefully and leave 1–2 mL medium behind depending on the pellet size.
Resuspend the pellet, stain dead cells with trypan blue, and count the purified Kupffer cells with a hemocytometer (i.e., Neubauer chamber) (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).

Plate Kupffer cells in Kupffer cells culture medium (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).
Incubate in 5% CO2 incubator at 37°C for 3 h and remove nonadherent cells with an aspirator. Kupffer cells on the plate can be resuspended by treatment with trypsin at 37°C for 3 min if there is a need.
Verify the purity of Kupffer cells by flow cytometry (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C–4F).

Co-culturing of HBV-positive hepatocytes and Kupffer cells
Timing: 3 days
Hepatocytes isolated from mice injected with the HBV DNA or from HBV transgenic mice are seeded at a density of ∼0.3 × 106 cells per well of a collagen-coated 6-well plate as described in step 33f.
Critical: The use of collagen-coated plate is necessary for maintaining the morphology and the differentiation phenotype of hepatocytes.
Place hepatocytes in a 37°C CO2 incubator for 4 h to allow the cells to attach to the plate and reach a confluency of 80%–90%.
Rinse cells once with DPBS and incubate them in the hepatocytes culture medium. If there is a need for long-term culturing, change the medium once every three days.
Note: Hepatocytes can be maintained for up to a week without notable change of morphology.
Perform the co-culturing experiment in the 6-well plate using the Transwell insert with 0.4 μm pore size for physical separation of two cell types.
Use sterile forceps to gently place Transwell inserts in each well above freshly attached hepatocytes.
Plate Kupffer cells at a density of 2 × 106 cells per Transwell insert. Co-culture Kupffer cells and HBV-positive hepatocytes in a medium containing 1:1 ratio of hepatocytes culture medium and Kupffer cells culture medium for three days.

By their design, Transwell inserts will be secured in place by the walls of the well. They will remain suspended in the media and not touch the bottom of the plate, allowing exchange of soluble factors between hepatocytes at the bottom and Kupffer cells in the ±insert.
Collect and replace the conditioned medium with fresh medium on day 1 after co-culturing at 37°C in a humidified incubator with 5% CO2, and collect the conditioned medium again on day 3.
Measure the levels of HBsAg and HBeAg using commercial ELISA kits following the manufacturer’s protocols[href=https://www.intlimmunodiagnostics.com/eia-hepatitis] (Li et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]). Examples of the ELISA results are shown in Figure 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig5].

Day before assay
Turn on the Agilent Seahorse XFe/XF Analyzer and allow it to warm up for at least 5 h.

Seed 105 Kupffer cells per well in Seahorse XF plate. Use appropriate medium for the cell culture. For Kupffer cells, use Kupffer cell culture medium for 200 μL/well.
Note: For more information, see the basic procedure, “Seeding Cells in Seahorse XF Cell Culture Microplates,” available at the Agilent Cell Analysis Learning Center[href=https://www.agilent.com/en/product/cell-analysis/how-to-run-an-assay].
Add water to the Seahorse XF sensor box, and then place the calibrators in a non-CO2 incubator16 h at 37°C.
Day of assay
Prepare XF medium and XF supplement in the cell culture hood. Transfer a sufficient amount of XF medium to a 50 mL tube.
Note: There is no need to warm up the medium and the supplement before this step.
Prepare the assay medium by supplementing Seahorse XF DMEM with 1 mM pyruvate, 2 mM glutamine, and 10 mM glucose.
Note: The medium composition can vary depending on the cell types or the desired experimental conditions.
Warm up the assay medium in a 37°C water bath before use.
Prepare compound stock solutions and working solutions
Take the foil bag and the decapper out from the Seahorse XF Cell Mito Stress Test Kit box.
Open the bag, remove the three test tubes containing oligomycin (blue cap), FCCP (yellow cap), and rotenone/antimycin A (red cap) and place them on a small test tube rack.
Insert the decapper’s tines into the cap’s inner lip and remove the cap from each tube.
Resuspend the contents of each tube with the volumes of assay medium shown in the Solution 1 table.
Gently pipet the medium up and down about 10 times to dissolve the compound.
Use the compound stock solution to prepare the working solution for loading into the injection port on the sensor cartridge. A constant compound concentration and variable loading volume approach is recommended for each compound.

Note: This method requires compound working solutions to be prepared at defined concentrations and different volumes of each compound to be loaded into the injection port (see Solution 2 table). For example, for the preparation of 20 μM oligomycin, mix 600 μL stock solution of oligomycin (100 μM) with 2,400 μL DMEM in the polystyrene reservoir. Load 20 μL diluted oligomycin (20 μM) per port using a multichannel pipette. Because the Seahorse XF cell culture microplate has 180 μL DMEM, the final concentration of oligomycin is 2 μM.
Prepare 2–3 mL of working solution for each compound in the analytical medium, using the volumes shown in the Solution 2 table for the XFe/XF96 analyzer.
Load compound solutions into the ports on sensor cartridge
The correct port loading technique can be found in the basic procedure “Loading Sensor Cartridges with Compounds” in the Agilent Cell Analysis Learning Center[href=https://www.agilent.com/en/product/cell-analysis/how-to-run-an-assay].Read the relevant information before loading the compound. In addition, make sure that the sensor box is adequately hydrated before use. Refer to Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] for port locations.

Prepare the Agilent Seahorse XF cell culture microplate for the assay
Remove the Seahorse XF cell culture microplate from the 37°C CO2 incubator and examine it under a microscope to confirm cell confluency.
Rinse Kupffer cells twice with 200 μL of Seahorse XF DMEM assay medium, leaving 20 μL behind after each rinse.
After the second rinse, add 160 μL of Seahorse XF DMEM assay medium to each well to a final volume of 180 μL/well.
Place the Seahorse XF cell culture microplate at 37°C without CO2 for 45 min to 1 h before running the assay.

Critical: It is essential to keep the culture microplate at 37°C without CO2 for 45 min to 1 h, as CO2 can interfere with the analysis.
Running the assay
Open the Wave software and retrieve the saved assay template file. Then, follow the instructions as described below:
Browse and open the saved design file, select the Review and Run tab, and click Start Run.
Place the sensor box with the calibration plate into the instrument and click “I am ready” when prompted. Calibration takes about 15–30 min (remove the cartridge lid and double-check to make sure that the microplate orientation is correct).
After calibrating and equilibrating the cell culture microplate, click “I am ready” when prompted.
Load the Seahorse XF cell culture microplate and click “I am ready” to run the assay.
Data analysis
The Seahorse XF Mito Stress Test Report Generator automatically calculates Seahorse XF Cell Mito stress test parameters from Wave data and export the data to Excel or GraphPad Prism (Li et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]) (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]A).

Day before assay
Turn on the Seahorse XFe/XF96 Analyzer and let the temperature stabilize.

Seed 105 Kupffer cells per well in the Agilent Seahorse XF Cell Culture Microplate using the Kupffer cells culture medium.
Hydrate a sensor cartridge in Seahorse XF Calibrant medium in a non-CO2 incubator at 37°C for 16 h.
For XFe/XF96 analyzers, select the Template for XF Glycolytic Rate Assay in Wave. Make necessary group modifications to tailor the template for the specific assay design.
Day of assay
Prepare Agilent Seahorse Glycolytic Rate assay medium: XF DMEM with 1 mM pyruvate, 2 mM glutamine, and 10 mM glucose. This medium contains an appropriate amount of HEPES and does not require pH adjustment.
Note: It is recommended to start with 1 mM pyruvate, 2 mM glutamine, and 10 mM glucose. However, the assay medium composition can vary depending on the cell type or the desired research conditions.
Prepare the XF medium and XF supplement in the cell culture hood. Transfer a sufficient amount of XF medium to a 50 mL tube.
Note: There is no need to warm up the medium and the supplement before this step.
Prepare the assay medium by adding XF supplement to XF medium to the desired concentration.
Note: No pH adjustment is required when using the recommended supplement concentration.
Warm up the assay medium in a 37°C water bath.
Prepare agilent seahorse XF cell culture microplates for assays
Remove the Seahorse XF cell culture microplate from the 37°C CO2 incubators and examine it under a microscope to confirm confluency and good cell morphology.
Critical: The cell quality and confluency are important for the assay.
Remove the cell culture medium from the Seahorse XF cell culture. Next, rinse cells twice with 200 μL warm Seahorse XF DMEM assay medium using a multichannel pipette. Leave 20 μL behind after each rinse.

After the second rinse, add 160 μL of Seahorse XF DMEM assay medium to each well and incubate cells in the assay medium in a non-CO2 incubator at 37°C for 45–60 min before the assay.
Remove the assay medium again and add 160 μL of fresh and warm Seahorse XF DMEM assay medium to each well for a final volume of 180 μL/well assay medium. The cells are now ready for the XF assay.
Prepare stock compounds
Remove the foil bag from the kit box, open the bag and take out the red cap vial Rot/AA and the green cap vial 2-DG.
Tap the vial to make sure that the powder is at the bottom of the tube before opening the vial.
Prepare the relevant assay medium as shown in the Solution 3 table using a P1000 pipette. Vortex the tubes for 1 min to ensure thorough dissolution of the compounds.
Diluting the compounds
The dilution of compounds for loading the cartridge is shown in the Solution 4 table. It is important to note that if a different starting assay volume or port volume is used, the compound concentrations will need to be adjusted to obtain the correct final concentrations for each well.
Load sensor cartridge
Standard Assay - No compound injection is required before the glycolytic rate assay. Load the compound into the following ports of the hydrated sensor cartridge (Figure 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig6] and the Solution 4 table):
Port A: For injection of Rot/AA.
Port B: For injection of 2-DG.
Running the assay
Download the Agilent Seahorse Glycolytic Rate template into the Seahorse XFe analyzer. If the Seahorse XFe template already exists, this step can be skipped.
Run the seahorse XFe/XF96 glycolytic rate assay
Select Seahorse XF Glycolytic Rate Assay template from the list of available templates and click Design.

Confirm or modify the default groups and conditions in specific assays in the section Groups/Conditions.
License plate map for your assay: Confirm or modify the default groups and conditions in the specific assay.
Assign the distribution of the samples.
Place the sensor box with the calibration plate into the instrument and click “I am ready” when prompted. Calibration takes about 15–30 min.
Note: Remove the cartridge lid and double-check to ensure that the microplate orientation is correct.
After calibrating and equilibrating the cell culture microplate, click “I am ready” when prompted.
Load the Seahorse XF cell culture microplate and click “I am ready” to run the assay.
Analysis using the agilent seahorse glycolytic rate assay report generator
The XF Glycolytic Rate Assay Report Generator automatically calculates Seahorse XF Glycolytic Rate Assay test parameters from Wave data that are exported to Excel or GraphPad Prism (Li et al., 2022[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]) (Figure 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig7]B).
